header.title: EL FOLCLOR MÉDICO DE CUBA - Enfermedades de la piel

central_thesis: This work meticulously documents traditional Cuban folk remedies for various skin ailments, demonstrating a syncretic system where empirically observed plant properties are interwoven with magical beliefs regarding illness causation and supernatural intervention. The efficacy of these remedies is often attributed to the inherent magical potency of substances, specific ritual actions, the faith of the patient, and the innate 'gracia' (divine gift) of the healer. It provides a practical compendium of operative folk magic focused on restoring corporeal health through non-conventional means.

structure_content.summary: Remedies for acne often combine topical applications of plant infusions (e.g., Guacamaya francesa, Túa-túa, Guásima, Maravilla, Guayaba, Yerba mora, Caguajasa) or animal products (e.g., cow dung, horse dung, majá lard) with beliefs about 'impure blood' or 'bad digestion' as root causes. Some practices include controversial elements such as applying menstrual blood or personal urine, attributed with potent, albeit mysterious, healing properties.

This condition, described as a severe, multi-mouthed infection, is treated with a blend of herbal remedies (e.g., Frailecillo, Gaguasí, Rascabarriga, Guayaba, Sandoval, Yerba mora) and sympathetic magic involving animal products (e.g., wasp nests, gunpowder from bullets, sapo/frog). Ritualistic applications often involve hot compresses, burning with a hot spoon, or strong purgatives to 'purify the blood' and counteract the perceived 'infection' or 'malevolence' causing the ailment.

Culebrilla (shingles) is conceptualized as a living 'snake' or 'animal' beneath the skin, threatening the patient's life if it encircles the body. Healing rituals are highly symbolic and operative, focusing on 'killing,' 'cutting,' or 'banishing' this entity. Methods include applying plant extracts (e.g., Marquesada, Naranja, Ítamo Real, Tabaibilla, Tilo Criollo), animal parts (e.g., guanajo/turkey blood, duck feathers), or even urine, often accompanied by specific prayers, cross gestures, and declarations of intent to 'sever' the illness.

Eczema is attributed to environmental factors (heat, sweat, damp earth) or internal imbalances ('parasites,' 'bad blood'). Remedies range from herbal washes and poultices (e.g., Piñón de Botija, Jobo, Marabú, Limón, Cundeamor, Sandoval, Tabaco, Guayaba, Diez del Día, Bijáguara, Guacamayón, Gandul, Sabanilla, Yuca Agria, Yerba Mora) to applications of animal fats (carnero/sheep fat) and other household substances (laundry soap, creoline, sugar paste, gunpowder, corn cobs) to dry, cool, or disinfect the affected area.

Erisipela, often termed a 'rose of fire,' is believed to stem from 'hot blood,' 'impurities,' or even supernatural malevolence ('demon's touch,' 'witch's kiss'). Healing is predominantly ritualistic, involving 'cutting' and 'banishing' the illness. Common practices include passing live frogs over the skin, using specific plants (e.g., Macurije, Tocino/Acacia tenuifolia, Guayaba, Salvia, Ponasí/Hamelia patens, Yerba Mora, Cundeamor, Sandoval, Yerba de Guinea, Yaba) with incantations, tying red ribbons, and employing objects like knives or scissors in symbolic 'severing' actions, often emphasizing the healer's 'gracia'.

Golondrinos (boils/hidradenitis) are often linked to 'impure blood,' clogged pores, or extracted hair. Remedies utilize plants (e.g., Tomate, Piñón de Botija, Malva de Cochinos, Malva Blanca, Yuca Agria), animal products (lard, chicken egg, majá fat), and unusual ritualistic practices. These include wearing clothes inside out, carrying specific small papers, and consuming highly taboo substances like 'casabe cake' (feces), all aimed at 'bursting' or 'disappearing' the boils through sympathetic or contagion magic.

Reactions to the toxic guao plant are considered a potent allergic response or even a curse from a 'maldijo Dios' plant. Remedies focus on counteracting the inflammation and 'heat' through plant washes (e.g., Bijáguara, Rascabarriga, Guásima, Yaba), animal fats (carnero/sheep fat), and various household preparations (coffee grounds, almidón paste, urine, toothpaste). One specific ritual involves returning to the offending plant and performing a 'Credo' while severing the plant, a form of banishing.

Lepra is attributed to severe 'decomposition' or 'fermentation' of the blood, or 'stagnant air.' Remedies, often described as lengthy, involve powerful internal depuratives and external washes using a wide array of plants (e.g., Palma Real, Cacao, Yerba de la Sangre, Platanillo de Cuba, Guayaba, Caimeitillo Cimarrón, Ítamo Real, Yerba Mora, Maboa, Sasafrás, Chirimoya, Alga, Yaba). Historical accounts also include using gunpowder mixed with lime juice, reflecting a belief in substances with strong alchemical or 'destructive' properties against the disease.

key_concepts.definition: An innate, often divinely bestowed, gift or special ability to heal, possessed by certain individuals, making their magical remedies more potent. It can be inherited or discovered incidentally.

A prevalent folk explanation for various skin ailments, positing that the blood is 'unclean,' 'hot,' 'fermented,' or otherwise corrupted, leading to external manifestations on the skin. Remedies often aim to 'purify' or 'cool' the blood.

A poultice or plaster, typically applied warm or hot to the afflicted area, composed of crushed herbs, animal products, or other substances. It serves as a vehicle for the magical and medicinal properties.

A magical operation involving the symbolic or literal 'cutting,' 'severing,' or 'neutralizing' of an illness. This is often performed with a blade, scissors, or other sharp objects, accompanied by specific prayers or declarations of intent, to 'exorcise' the disease from the body.

A central symptom or perceived cause of many skin diseases, characterized by intense burning or heat. Remedies frequently focus on drawing out or counteracting this 'heat' using 'cooling' substances or symbolic actions.
Patient belief or faith in the remedy and the healer is considered a critical, often indispensable, component for the successful outcome of many traditional and magical cures.

A common folk belief, particularly for conditions like 'culebrilla,' where the illness is personified as a living creature residing and moving beneath the skin, actively causing harm and attempting to 'strangle' the host.
Solanum nodiflorum, a versatile plant frequently mentioned across various remedies for its perceived purifying and healing properties, used both internally and externally.

A principle where 'like affects like,' or a part affects the whole. Examples include using parts of the perceived 'source' of an ailment (e.g., wasp nest for avispero) or mimicking the desired outcome (e.g., 'cutting' the culebrilla with scissors).

practical_system.description: The system outlined is a practical folk magic system for healing skin diseases, blending empirical plant knowledge with a magical cosmology where illness causation extends beyond the physical. It integrates herbalism, animal products, and everyday items into ritualistic applications. Efficacy is often linked to the healer's innate 'gracia', the patient's 'fe', and the precise execution of specific operations to 'cut', 'cleanse', or 'banish' the perceived disease entity.
tools: Medicinal plants: Yerba Mora (Solanum nodiflorum), Guayaba (Psidium guajaba), Limón (Citrus limonum), Piñón de Botija (Jatropha curcas), Ítamo Real (Pedilanthus tithymaloides), Túa-túa (Jatropha gossypifolia), Guásima (Guazuma tomentosa), Maravilla (Mirabilis jalapa), Bijáguara (Colubrina arborescens), Rascabarriga (Ouratea agrophylla), Salvia (Salvia officinalis), Sandoval (Hyptis sp.), Tabaco (Nicotiana tabacum), Tomate (Lycopersicum esculentum).

Animal products: Lard (cerdo/puerco, majá), Chicken eggs (gallina), Dung (buey/vaca, caballo), Live animals (rana/frog), Animal parts (guanajo/turkey leg, duck feather, wasp nests, sapo/toad), Gunpowder from bullets, Carnero/sheep fat.
Household items: Knives, scissors, hot spoons, cloth/rags, paper, soap (yellow laundry soap), bottles, jars, mortar and pestle.
Bodily fluids: Saliva, urine, menstrual blood.
Mineral substances: Sulfur, creoline, borax, talc, almidón (starch), salt, sugar.
Water: Boiled water, sea water, water with specific herbal infusions.
Fire/heat: Candela (open flame), rescoldo (embers), hot compresses.
Intent and Will: The conscious direction of magical energy and purpose by the healer and patient.
Faith ('Fe'): Essential belief in the power of the remedy and healer.
Gracia: The innate healing gift of the practitioner.
rituals: Ritualistic 'cutting' or 'severing' of the illness using objects like knives, scissors, or duck feathers, often performed in a cross pattern over the afflicted area.
Application of poultices ('guataplasmas') made from specific herbs, animal products (e.g., dung, fats), or bodily wastes, often applied warm or hot.

Verbal incantations and prayers invoking divine names (Dios, Jesús, Santa María, San Francisco, San Bartolomé) or direct commands to the illness (e.g., '¡Culebrilla yo te mato!', '¡Vete para el infierno!').
Bathing or washing with herbal infusions (e.g., Yerba Mora, Guayaba) or specially prepared waters (e.g., salted water, water boiled with specific ingredients).
Sympathetic magic, such as using a wasp nest to treat 'avispero' or cutting a turkey's leg for 'culebrilla,' to transfer properties or neutralize the illness.
Performance of actions a specific number of times (e.g., three, seven, nine times) for magical amplification.
Rituals involving the disposal of ritualistic materials (burning, burying, throwing away) to ensure the disease does not return or affect others.
Consuming specific purgatives or foods (e.g., 'casabe cake' for golondrinos) to 'purify' the blood or expel internal impurities.
Symbolic actions involving wearing clothes inside out or placing specific objects (e.g., small white papers, lemons) in pockets to deflect or cure ailments.
Use of taboo substances like urine, menstrual blood, or animal dung, believed to possess powerful, often paradoxical, healing properties.

relevant_quotes.text: No sé qué propiedad pueden tener en las manos las mujeres con el periodo. ¡Es un misterio!
El propio meado es un remedio imperial, que quiere decir que no tiene igual, y eso se debe a la salecita que contiene.
¡En el nombre de Dios Padre, de Dios Hijo y de Dios Espíritu Santo. Estas hojas bendecidas, influenciadas por tu ser, son para poder ver la culebrilla vencida.
¡En el nombre y con la ayuda de Dios, esta culebrilla está matada!
La cabeza y el rabo te corto, Satanás. ¡Vete para el infierno y no vuelvas más!
¡Ésta es la rosa maldita que quema a la gente! ¡Yo la cortaré! ... ¡Y la botaré! ¡Gallo no canta, perro no ladra! ¡Esta erisipela ya está cortada!

Se coge un panal de avispas completo, con gusanos y todo, y freírlo en aceite de comer; luego, se separa el panal del sartén, se moja un paño en el aceite caliente y se pone una guataplasma sobre el avispero.

Una torta de casabe es una plasta de porquería, cagada en un papel bien limpio. Para hacer el remedio, se pone en el suelo un papel bien limpio, se agacha uno, caga, y cuando termina se empieza a comer la plasta con una cuchara, empezando por el borde, recogiendo en redondo. Al que hace el remedio no le salen golondrinos más nunca en su vida.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is exceptionally relevant for Western Esotericism and Occultism as it provides a raw, unfiltered ethnographic account of practical folk magic in a specific cultural context (Cuba). It demonstrates the lived application of magical principles, such as sympathetic magic, contagion, and banishing rituals, within a healing framework. The syncretism of indigenous, African, and European magical elements is evident throughout. It challenges a purely materialist view of illness, offering insights into how a magical worldview provides agency and meaning to suffering, particularly when conventional medicine is inaccessible or mistrusted. This text serves as a valuable resource for comparative magic studies, revealing the continuity of certain operative paradigms across diverse traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers in ethnomedicine, anthropology of religion, and the history of occultism; practitioners of folk magic, particularly those interested in Caribbean or Santería-influenced traditions; and advanced students seeking primary source material on the practical applications and underlying philosophies of traditional healing magic.
